Boost Log Library Documentation

Version 1.4

Thread-safety

The Boost Log library is thread-safe, while being efficient.

(As a side-note, ts_appender is a very useful Appender function).

Manipulating logs' behavior (doing any of: adding a Appender, or a Modifier or enabling/disabling logs), is thread-safe.

Whenever writing to a log, the first thing I will do is "ask if the message should be written to the log" (based on the log's level and message's level). 

BOOST_LOG(app) << whatever << you << want << to << write;
// OR
BOOST_LOGL(app,lvl) << whatever << you << want << to << write;

// equivalent to (pseudo-code):
// if ( can_write_message(app,lvl) ) app << whatever <<....;

If can_write_message returns true, the writing will take place (that is, whatever follows BOOST_LOG[L](..) gets executed). Otherwise, processing stops, thus whatever follows BOOST_LOG[L](...) does not get executed.

The can_write_message(...) test does not incur in a (mutex) lock (it would be too inefficient). Thus, once a thread enables/disables some log(s), it will take a short while for this to propagate to the other threads. This is not so bad, compared to the gains in efficiency.

In order for the changes to propagate instantly, you're encouraged to enable/disable logs at the beginning of the program (when only one thread is running).

Of course, you can - at any time -, enable/disable logs, as your application is running. It could prove very useful if you have a server application, a lot of active users, and - while running - you might want to enable additional logging.
